Psychology
7. Psychology

Kant’s views on psychology are intimately bound up with his more
general position in the philosophy of mind (see the separate entry on
this topic.) He distinguishes between rational and empirical
psychology and, in the Critique of Pure Reason’s
Paralogisms, denies that rational psychology contains arguments that
could justify any substantive principles (especially concerning our
immortality). Thus, only empirical psychology, it seems, could be
possible as a science. However, if Kant continues to maintain that
science requires a pure part, and denies that rational psychology
contains any substantive knowledge that might constitute the pure part
of psychology, then it follows that empirical psychology cannot
qualify as science proper either.

And yet, he did not count it as a proper science either. If we ask
why, we can discern two broad answers in the secondary literature.
Older interpretations thought it was because mathematization (a mark
of ‘proper’ science) is not feasible in psychology.
Supposedly, it is because psychic phenomena are in time—it is
their ordering structure, or a priori form—and time qua form
lacks enough features to support strong mathematization. (It is a
1-dimensional manifold representable as a line: too narrow to support
constructions in pure intuition, which mathematization would require.)
A more recent construal has it that empirical psychology lacks genuine
laws. Kant leaves open the prospect for it coming to have ‘laws
of association,’ viz. knowledge of patterns of constant
conjunction between some of our inner representations. Such patterns,
discoverable by introspection, may resemble laws properly so-called.
But, as some have argued recently, that is not enough. Genuine laws
require stronger warrant—primarily, evidence from successful
prediction confirmed by experiment or from precise observations. That
sort of evidence, interpreters believe, is not available in empirical
psychology. Which makes it an improper science by Kant’s lights:
even more improper than chemistry, which arguably does avail itself of
genuine laws explicated as above. A scholar who endorses the first
reading above is Hatfield 1992; for the second, see especially McNulty
2014.

Unsurprisingly, Kant influenced empirical theory in early 19th-century
Germany. (However, it was his transcendental psychology in the
Critique of Pure Reason, not his views on empirical
psychology, that proved to be most influential.) In particular, his
doctrine of space and time as forms of sensibility was given a
naturalistic construal in the physiology and psychology of perception.
Since for Kant an a priori form of intuition need not be innate, it
could unfold in the course of sensory experience. This led J.G.
Steinbuch (1811) and C. Th. Tourtual (1827) to investigate empirically
how spatial representation arises—specifically, how particular
subjects become able to see things as arrayed in space, perceive
objects as three-dimensional, and represent spatial structures more
generally.

Hatfield (1990, Chapter 4) surveys these post-Kantian developments in
more detail. Kitcher (1990) presents a detailed argument for the role
of transcendental psychology within Kant’s Critique of Pure
Reason. Sturm (2001) argues that Kant’s critical comments
about psychology are primarily directed against introspection-based
conceptions of psychology.
